Microcontroller â–ª A microcontroller is a small processor with a core, memory and integrated I/O peripherals such as timers, analog-to-digital converters, and serial communications [1]. â–ª Features of a microcontroller (MCU): â–ª Self Contained (CPU, Memory, I/O) â–ª Application or Task Specific (Not a general-purpose computer) â–ª Appropriately scaled for the job â–ª Small power consumption â–ª Low costs ( $0.50 to $5.00.) â–ª Microcontrollers are everywhere, many systems contain even multiple microcontrollers. â€¢[1] Embedded Systems with ARM Cortex-M Microcontrollers in Assembly Language and C, page 56 0 - 37 High-Level Block Diagram 0 - 38 High-Level Block Diagram Low Power CPU: â€¢ Enabling power to the rest of the system â€¢ Battery charging and voltage measurement â€¢ Wireless radio (boot and operate) â€¢ Detect and check expansion boards Higher Performance CPU: â€¢ Sensor reading and motor control â€¢ Flight control â€¢ Telemetry (including the battery voltage) â€¢ Additional user development â€¢ USB connection UART: â€¢ communication protocol (Universal Asynchronous Receiver/Transmitter) â€¢ Exchange of data packets to and from interfaces (wireless, USB) 0 - 39 High-Level Block Diagram Sensor Board:Acronyms: â€¢ Wkup: Wakeup signal â€¢ GPIO: General-purpose input/output signal â€¢ SPI: Serial Peripheral Interface Bus â€¢ I2C: Inter-Integrated Circuit (Bus) â€¢ PWM: Pulse-width modulated Signal â€¢ VCC: power-supply EEPROM: â€¢ Electrically erasable programmable read-only memory â€¢ Used for firmware (part of data and software that usually is not changed, e.g. configuration data) â€¢ Can not be easily overwritten in comparison to Flash Flash Memory: â€¢ Non-volatile random-access memory for program and data 0 - 40 High-Level Physical View 0 - 41 High-Level Physical View 0 - 42 Embedded Systems - Basics 0 - 43 Embedded Systems in a Picture â€“ An Overview // High-level language // C-source code int main (void){ int total = 0; This must be avoided! â–ª Pull-up or Pull-down resistors are used to provide a default voltage when the pin would otherwise be floating. â€¢[1] Embedded Systems with ARM Cortex-M Microcontrollers in Assembly Language and C, page 362 GPIO â€¢[1] GPIO â€¢[1] â–ª No Pull-Up. â–ª Pressed: 0V â–ª Else: Floating â–ª Pull-Up. â–ª Pressed: 0V â–ª Else: Vdd 0 - 56 GPIO: Pull-Up and Pull-Down Resistors â€¢Outside MCUâ€¢Inside MCU â–ª Pull-Up or Pull-Down Resistors can be soldered to the PCB, or internally enabled by software. 0 - 57 GPIO: Outputs â€¢Outside MCUâ€¢Inside MCU â–ª Digital outputs control the voltage on the pin.
